TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit CombinedGeometry extends System.Windows.Media.Geometry
Public NotInheritable Class CombinedGeometry Inherits Geometry
public ref class CombinedGeometry sealed : System::Windows::Media::Geometry
.class public auto ansi sealed CombinedGeometry extends System.Windows.Media.Geometry

Docs.summary: Represents a 2-D geometric shape defined by the combination of two objects.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Media.CombinedGeometry.GeometryCombineMode%2A> property specifies how the two geometries will be combined. Note that <xref:System.Windows.Media.CombinedGeometry> combines the area specified by two geometries, so geometries that do not have area (such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.LineGeometry>) disappear when combined.
Geometries can be combined in several ways: using a <xref:System.Windows.Media.GeometryGroup>, a <xref:System.Windows.Media.CombinedGeometry>, or the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.Combine%2A> method of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> class.
- A <xref:System.Windows.Media.GeometryGroup> creates a composite geometry from one or more <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> objects.
- A <xref:System.Windows.Media.CombinedGeometry> uses a specified boolean operation to combine the area described by two <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> objects.
- The static <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.Combine%2A> method of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> class behaves in exactly the same manner as the <xref:System.Windows.Media.CombinedGeometry> object.
Careful thought should be involved when using a <xref:System.Windows.Media.CombinedGeometry> to perform a union as it can be very CPU-expensive. In most cases, a <xref:System.Windows.Media.GeometryGroup> or <xref:System.Windows.Media.PathGeometry.AddGeometry%2A> will work better.
Use a <xref:System.Windows.Media.CombinedGeometry> only when any of the following apply:
- The geometric operation is not a union.
- Either of the geometries have a <xref:System.Windows.Media.FillRule> value of <xref:System.Windows.Media.FillRule.EvenOdd> and the geometries are self-intersecting (i.e. the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FillRule> actually matters).
- Time is not a concern, but space is (for instance, if the geometry is created once and then cached). Typically, <xref:System.Windows.Media.CombinedGeometry> produces smaller output than <xref:System.Windows.Media.PathGeometry.AddGeometry%2A>.
- The resulting geometry will be stroked or used in a path animation and <xref:System.Windows.Media.PathGeometry.AddGeometry%2A> does not provide the desired outline.
## Freezable Features A <xref:System.Windows.Media.CombinedGeometry> is a type of <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> object. For information about <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> features, such as freezing and cloning, see the [Freezable Objects Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/freezable-objects-overview.md).

## Remarks This method is used to produce modifiable copies of frozen <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> objects (or any <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> object). For convenience, this method shadows the inherited version with a strongly typed implementation.
For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.Clone%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType>.
